title: How your clothes are poisoning our oceans and food supply
body: New studies indicate that the fibers in our clothes could be poisoning our waterways and food chain on a massive scale. Microfibers - tiny threads shed from fabric - have been found in abundance on...
readable_content:
The Guardian (2023-12-08): Microplastic pollution has become a significant threat to our oceans, largely due to the shedding of synthetic fibers from our clothes. This overlooked form of pollution has the potential to devastate aquatic life and impact the food chain. A study has revealed that synthetic fleece jackets release a significant amount of microfibers during each wash, which then find their way into water bodies. What's more concerning is that these plastic fibers have the potential to bioaccumulate, ultimately concentrating toxins in larger animals higher up the food chain.

Research has indicated that microfibers are not only found in marine environments but are also prevalent in freshwater systems, posing a widespread environmental threat. The impact on marine life is evident as evidenced by studies involving crabs, which showed altered behavior and potential stunted growth after being exposed to food contaminated with microfibers.

Even though companies in the outdoor industry, such as Patagonia, have taken steps to address the microfiber issue, the situation remains alarming. The microfiber problem underscores the need for greater awareness and action to mitigate the environmental impact of synthetic clothing materials.
